questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the secondary level of the healthcare system?
questions.solution:
Medical colleges are included in the tertiary level of the health care system, which is also the second referral centre.

Related Pearl: Levels of Healthcare System in India

questions.text: Which of the following is not an element of primary healthcare?
questions.solution:
Providing physical rehabilitation is not an element of primary health care. Primary health centers (PHCs) are only responsible for the popularization and mainstreaming of PMR in the community.

Primary health care refers to essential health care made universally available to individuals and acceptable to them, through their full participation and at a cost the community and country can afford.

Related Pearl: Elements and Principles of Primary Health Care

A. Elements of Primary Health Care

(Mnemonic: ELEMENTS)

  • Education about health problems and their prevention and control
  • Locally endemic diseases – prevention and control
  • Essential drugs
  • Maternal and child health care
  • Expanded programme of immunization against vaccine preventable diseases
  • Nutrition and proper food supply
  • Treatment of common diseases and injuries
  • Safe water and sanitation

B. Principles/Pillars of Primary Health Care

  • Equitable distribution
  • Community participation
  • Intersectoral coordination
  • Appropriate technology

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding ASHA workers?

choices.text: Few of their responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers
They should have formal education at least up to class 10
A population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA
They have to procure ORS, OCPs, IFA tablets from CHC

questions.solution:
Accredited social health activist (ASHA) workers do not need to procure supplies from CHCs. They only act as depot holders for certain essential supplies so that they are readily available to their community.

These essential supplies may include ORS, contraceptives, iron-folic acid tablets, chloroquine, disposable delivery kits, oral contraceptive pills, condoms, etc. 

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding Anganwadi workers?

choices.text: One AWW serves a population of 5000
They are appointed under the ICDS scheme
They link the community with the health services
Their responsibilities include counsel for immunization, health education, and nutrition

questions.solution:
The norm is one Anganwadi worker (AWW) per 400-800 population.

Anganwadi workers (AWW) are allotted under the integrated child development services (ICDS). AWW are selected from the community they are to serve and act as links between the community and health services. They are mostly part-time workers.

Responsibilities of an AWW include:

  • Health checkups and growth chart maintenance
  • Counsel women on birth preparedness, importance of safe delivery, immunization and contraception and prevention of common infections including STD and RTIs.
  • Nutrition
  • Health education
  • Non-formal school education
  • Referral services

questions.text:
Which of the following duties would be performed by a male health worker?
  1. Chlorination of water bodies
  2. Maintenance of eligible couple registers
  3. Distribution of conventional contraceptives
  4. Universal Immunization Program
  5. Reproductive and child health services
questions.solution:
The duties of a male health worker include chlorination of water bodies, distribution of conventional contraceptives, and reproductive and child health services.

Maintanence of eligible couple registers (part of family planning activities) and immunization are duties of female health workers.

Health workers (male and female) are 1 per 5000 in plains and 1 per 3000 in remote or hilly areas.

questions.text: Which of the following are not involved in providing antenatal support to pregnant women?
questions.solution:

  • Health workers (male and female) - 1 per 5000 in plains and 1 per 3000 in hilly or remote areas.
  • Health assistants (male and female) - 1 per 30,000 in plains and 1 per 20, 000 in remote or hilly areas.
  • Anganwadi workers - 1 per 400-800 in plains and 1 per 300-800 in hilly or remote areas.

questions.text: What should be the maximum number of female health workers at a sub-center?
questions.solution:
Two female health workers are to be at a sub-center as proposed by the Indian Public Health Standards (IPHS).

There are two types of sub-centers:

  • Type A - It has all facilities except for conducting deliveries. It can be upgraded to Type B.
  • Type B - Also called MCH sub-centers. It has delivery facilities.

*To be outsourced

questions.text: One community health center (CHC) covers a population of:
questions.solution:
Each community (CHC) covers a population of 80,000-1,20,000.

Services provided by CHC:

  • Care of routine and emergency cases in medicine and surgery
  • Maternal, newborn, and child health
  • Family planning
  • All the functions of national health programmes
  • Physical medicine and rehabilitation
  • Oral health
  • School and adolescent health services
  • Blood storage facility
  • Diagnostic services
  • Referral services
  • Maternal death review (MDR)

FRU- First referral unit

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the staffing at urban primary health centers?
questions.solution:
An urban primary health center will cover 50,000-60,000 population and will be staffed with:

  • Two doctors (one regular and one on a part-time basis) 
  • 3 staff nurses
  • 1 pharmacist
  • 1 lab technician
  • 1 lady health visitor
  • 4–5 ANMs (depending upon the population covered)
  • Other clerical and support staff and one program manager

Basic functions provided are:

  • OPD
  • Basic lab diagnosis
  • Drug/contraceptive dispensing
  • Health education along with referral services

*Note: The above data is according to IPHS 2017 guidelines. The revised guidelines as per IPHS 2022 have been listed in the pearl attached below.

International Nurses Day is an international day observed around the world on 12 May of each year, to mark the contributions that nurses make to society.

Related Pearl: Primary Health Centres-PHC

  • HWC-PHCs: Population of 30000 in plains, 20000 in hilly/tribal areas
  • Urban HWC-PHCs: Population of 50000
  • Specialist UPHC/Polyclinic (urban): Population of 2.5- 3 lakh

PHC’s and UPHC’s can be further extended to 24X7 PHC’s/UPHC’s

questions.text: Which of the following is the principal unit of administration in India?
questions.solution:
The principal unit of administration in India is the district under a collector.

Under districts are the sub-divisions, tahsils or talukas, municipalities or corporations, villages, panchayats, etc. As of 2021, there are 748 districts in India.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrectly matched?
questions.solution:
The Panchayat Samiti or Janpada Panchayat operates at the block level.

Panchayati Raj is a three-tier structure of rural self-government in India. It operates at the following levels:

  • Panchayat at the village level (includes Gram Sabha, Gram Panchayat, and Nyaya Panchayat)
  • Panchayat Samiti or Janpada Panchayat at the block level
  • Zilla Parishad at the district level

questions.text: Community or village health guides are selected by:
questions.solution:
Village health guides (VHGs) are selected by the medical officer-in-charge (MO).

2-3 candidates are put forward by the community for the position of a VHG. The MO selects one of them after consultation with the block development officer and field staff.

questions.text: As a PHC medical officer, you would keep all of the following in mind while selecting a village health guide except:

choices.text: They must be above 45 years of age
They must be a resident of the community that they will serve
They must be educated up to 6th grade
They should be able to spare 2-3 hours in a day for community work

questions.solution:
Village health guides (VHG) are chosen by the medical officer-in-charge (including PHC MO). Age is not a criterion for selection.

The VHG scheme was introduced in 1977. Guidelines for choosing a VHG include: 

  • They can be of either sex but must be residents of the village
  • They must know to read and write and have education up to 6th grade
  • They must be able to spare around 2-3 hours a day for community work
  • They must be acceptable to all parts of the community

VHGs are trained for 2-3 months before beginning work. The norm is to have 1 VHG per 1000 population.
